name: The Assassin Hunter - Fighter 8 / DwD 6 / Assassin 26
author: Valerfor

posts.author: Maximillian_Kane
posts.content:
Hail, Mighty ECBers!

The idea behind this character was to make an Assassin that specialized in assassinating Assassins. He studied their techniques for years and is now able to execute them with perfection, but instead of selling his services as a killer-for-hire like all of them, he decided it would be more profitable to sell his services to those who had a prize on their heads and build a reputation that instilled fear on all Assassins. Once the first Assassin sent to do the job fell, it would discourage future Assassination attempts from taking place, after word got out that the mark was under the protection of the Assassin Hunter. It worked like a charm, and soon he was charging obscene amounts of gold to protect prominent people who were marked for death from the first attempt, and a moderate upkeep fee to announce they're under his protection. To this day, no Assassins have succeeded on attempts against people protected by this mysterious man.

So, I thought to myself, what would be a counter-assassin? The first thing I remembered was my Underdark Expeditioner, where I used Dwarven Defender just to become immune to Sneak Attacks in a build that had lots of d6 of Sneak Attacks itself. Combining this with Assassin, you now have a brutal murderer who will not end his enemy's life swiftly. He will wait for the ambush to occur, and spring his brutal trap. He will most likely paralyze them on the first strike, but even if that doesn't work, he won't use traps or any other shenanigans, he will simply use his affinity with Darkness to sneak the crap out of Assassins, while they watch in horror as they hit him with their best weapons and moves, and he comes out of it nearly unscathed. 

He has 26 levels of Assassin, making his Death Attack DC really high at 38, especially factoring in INT-enhancing items and buffs, where it can go up to 44 with Capped INT. He has 13d6 Death Attack damage, and he doesn't really want to be subtle, so he comes at his enemies with a Dwarven Waraxe and a high(ish) STR score to mutilate his enemies and send a message against future attempts.

Ladies and Gentlemen, The Assassin Hunter!

EDIT: As Kfor85 suggested, in places where immunity to KD is common, Discipline becomes droppable, and can be replaced with Spot or Listen to detect hidden creatures. This also means you can take Fighter 8 much earlier in the build (at level 25, just after EWF, for earlier EWS), since you won't need the late skill dump. Then, that last Epic Skill Focus should be taken in whatever detection skill you choose.

EDIT 2: Another way to do it without changing anything else would be to drop CON to 12, and increase INT to 16. Now you have 43 extra Skill points, which can be invested into a detection skill. This also has the good side effect of raising your DA DC by 1. (but you lose 80 HP!)

Actually, it is an Assassin.  The best Assassin there is, to be honest.  Nightshades are an exclusive Class, first originating among the Ghost Elves, before the Sundering, and then after the Ghost Elves disappeared from the Prime (and interned in the Hells), the Drow took them in, twisted them, made them even deadlier.

I know, I know, lots of Monk, some SD, 1 Ass.  But much more an Assassin as the Assassin PrC.  And with Albino Drow...they can pass for Surface Elves as well.  If the Drow Race was allowed to be played, then one would not need so many Monk levels to simulate Drow SR.  Then one could take more Assassin levels.

We build with what we have.

I would very much like to see your Anti-Monk!

With WoG in mind, that works, because you have KD immunity items. But if such items weren't available, dropping Discipline wouldn't be an option IMO. In that case, you could either go with the second version of the build or drop Stealth skills, and use Invisibility wands instead as your source of sneaking. There are certainly many options for ways you can tweak this build, all of which are environment-dependant. That floor of said Wizard's Tower is a problem without detection, but less so if one is immune to Sneak Attacks, as most of their damage output comes from them. 

Cheers!
